isis.stitle: INTERNATIONAL® VT 365 DIESEL ENGINE - CRANKCASE, CRANKSHAFT and BEARINGS, CAMSHAFT and BUSHINGS - Cleaning, Inspection, and Reconditioning - Crankcase Assembly

note.para: Clean the crankcase in a chemical bath or hot tank. This removes all carbonized material and mineral deposits in coolant passages.
Thoroughly clean and inspect crankcase before and after reconditioning.

step1.para: Use nonmetalic brushes and scrapers to clean gasket material from machined surfaces of crankcase.
Clean cylinder bore with soap, water, and a nylon brush.
Clean lower crankcase in solvent. Dry with filtered compressed air.

warning.para: To prevent personal injury or death, wear safety glasses with side shields to protect eyes.

step1.para: To remove main oil gallery cup plug (in rear of crankcase), use a punch and hammer near edge of plug and strike with a hammer. Remove plug from crankcase and discard. Clean main oil galleries with a Oil Gallery Cleaning Brush .

figure.caption: Figure 305. Removal of oil gallery cup plugs

step1.para: Clean main galleries with an Oil Gallery Cleaning Brush .

note.para: Use Liquid Gasket (RTV) before installing main oil gallery core plugs.

step1.para: Coat edges of new cup plugs with sealant. Use a Oil Gallery Plug Driver to install new cup plugs. The Oil Gallery Plug Driver installs cup plug to the proper depth. It should be flush with the crankcase surface to approximately 1.50 mm (0.060 in) below surface.

caution.para: To prevent engine damage, threads in the crankcase bolt holes must be clean and blown dry with filtered compressed air.

step1.para: Clean all cylinder head bolt holes with a Head Bolt Bottoming Tap . Blow out chips with filtered compressed air.
After cleaning, inspect crankcase for cracks, scoring, roughness or wear at cylinder bores.

figure.caption: Figure 308. Flatness check for top surface of cylinder block

step1.para: Use a Straightedge to check top surface of crankcase (top deck) for flatness. Insert a feeler gauge between Straightedge and crankcase head surface. If gap exceeds specifications , crankcase must be replaced.

caution.para: Do not resurface the crankcase. Surface defects beyond those listed above are not correctable.

step1.para: If cylinder walls have minor surface damage, but are otherwise within out-of-round specifications, it may be possible to remove such damage by honing.
Use a Cylinder Bore Gauge to check cylinder bore out-of-round conditions.

Measure diameter of cylinder bore at top of piston ring travel. Be sure to measure at a right angle to the center line of crankshaft (dimension A). Record reading. Next, measure each bore so gauge reading coincides with center line of crankshaft (dimension B). Record reading.

The difference between readings from dimension A and dimension B is the out-of-round condition at the top of the cylinder bore. Repeat the same procedure at the bottom of ring travel to check for out-of-round condition.

caution.para: To prevent engine damage, if cylinder bores are deeply scored, out-of-round, or exceed specifications, all cylinders must be bored out to an oversize.

step1.para: If cylinder bore is within specifications , standard size pistons and rings may be used. If cylinder bore is suitable for use without reconditioning, deglaze the cylinder bore before assembling. See Cylinder Deglazing in this section.

note.para: If cylinder bores are to be deglazed, all piston cooling tubes must be removed.

step1.para: Use a 4 inch Deglazing Hone to deglaze the cylinder bore. This silicone carbide-tipped nylon flexible brush quickly deglazes cylinder walls and produces a crosshatch pattern on the cylinder wall surface in a single operation. The brush contours itself to the cylinder wall and conditions wall surface without altering cylinder bore.
Spray both the cylinder to be deglazed and the Deglazing Hone brush with penetrating fluid or equivalent. This spray contains colloidal graphite and works well for this application.

step2.para: Attach Deglazing Hone to a variable speed electric or air powered drill.

note.para: 100-120 rpm and speed adjustment is required.

step2.para: Deglaze cylinder wall for about 15 seconds. Stroke bore up and down at a rate of one complete up and down stroke per second.
Withdraw Deglazing Hone from cylinder bore while brush is rotating. Wipe portion of cylinder wall and inspect cross-hatch pattern.

note.para: The crosshatch pattern left by the abrasive tool should be approximately 45°.

step2.para: If pattern is "flatter" than required, increase up and down stroke speed or slow down drill rotation.
Continue deglazing cylinder bore for 10-15 seconds or 20-25 strokes.
Wipe cylinder bore clean and inspect bore for proper 45° cross-hatch pattern.

step1.para: After deglazing, thoroughly clean cylinder bores with soft bristle brush, soap and water. Dry with filtered compressed air . Lubricate bore with clean engine oil.
